image_text: 2010 - 2016: Little water flowed into the Oroville reservoir during the drought years.
2017: Big storms produce tremendous water inflow.
February 2017: Winter storms filled Oroville and outflow began to increase.
Officials underestimated the rising reservoir level and only began to increase outflow when there was no room left in the reservoir.
Four ways to outflow water from the reservoir: All were unequal to the outflow needed due to the storm and high reservoir levels. Let's look at each in more depth.
The emergency spillway: Used for the first time during the storm but the hillside began dangerously eroding within a day.
Main spillway: Damaged February 7 and releasing reduced flow to prevent further damage.
Edward Hyatt Powerplant: Non-operational; turned off to prevent damage to it after the main spillway was damaged.
River outlet: Rarely used since a 2009 accident that injured dam workers. Now releasing up to 2,000 cfs.
Using the emergency spillway eroded the hillside.
Many residents were displaced due to fears of flooding.
We might be through the rainy season, but what is going to happen when the snow starts to melt? Check the current status of the reservoirs and the snowpack.
